report_title: Industry Report on Precast Concrete Product Manufacturing
executive_summary: The industry supplies US building and infrastructure construction markets with one of the most ubiquitous inputs for large-scale construction projects. Products made by manufacturers range from slabs and roof tiles for apartments to beams and trusses for bridges and highways. Manufacturers also produce precast manholes, water retention structures and catch basins for water infrastructure and concrete panels, posts and poles to erect electrical distribution facilities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Two federal multiyear funding packages have uplifted the transportation infrastructure market: the Fixing America's Surface Transportation (FAST) Act

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Create Volatility in the Building Construction Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The construction market has grappled with many deterrents over the past few years. First, businesses rising office vacancies and declining corporate profit during the pandemic forced businesses to put off construction plans. Even so, near-zero interest rates at the onset of the period sustained the housing market.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Major Manufacturers Leverage Size and Reputation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry's most prominent manufacturers have turned to vertical integration in an effort to cut down supply costs and limit profit declines.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Funding for Transit Infrastructure Construction Drives Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Funding for transit infrastructure construction has driven demand for prestressed concrete panels, columns, railroad ties, culverts and blocks. Even so, bridge and elevated highway construction remain volatile. These buyers are reliant on cyclical government spending and face exposure to policy changes that come with new administrations. If federal funding dries up, this market collapses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Green Energy Shift Creates Demand for New Utilities Infrastructure
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the United States population grows, more significant investments will be needed to maintain the country's already aging energy infrastructure system. In particular, power, water and sewage systems need constant upkeep and upgrades.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Precast Concrete Manufacturers Strive for Net-Neutral Production
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In 2023, BBC News reported that concrete manufacturers accounted for roughly 8.0% of the world's carbon emissions. Precast concrete manufacturers have focused on reducing carbon dioxide emissions by improving mix designs. This trend will hasten as manufacturers appeal to contractors who opt for sustainable building materials.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Building Construction Market Will Rebound
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Significant interest rate hikes have stifled demand for new construction projects over the current period. Interest rates are not expected to climb as significantly through 2029 compared to during the current period, enabling the construction market to recover slowly.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures precast and prestressed concrete products for use in various construction markets. Industry products include precast concrete slabs and panels, building boards, roofing tiles, railroad ties, posts, poles, prestressed bridge beams and trusses. The production of concrete blocks, bricks and pipes is excluded from this industry. The production of ready-mix concrete is also excluded from this industry.
key_trends: Manufacturers secure contracts with suppliers. Successful precast concrete manufacturers leverage established networks to source less expensive materials than competitors.

Buyers choose manufacturers based on price and quality. The most successful manufacturers place an emphasis on producing a diverse range of products that exceed minimum load-bearing requirements. Delivery time is also key to success.

Federal infrastructure spending drives demand from key buyers, especially as rising interest rates deter companies from starting new projects. The nation's utilities and roadways are constantly being repaired, driving the need for precast concrete structures.
Green initiatives will push manufacturers to produce low-emission concretes. Precast concrete manufacturers will face added competition from substitutions.
Major manufacturers struggle to expand their reach. High transportation costs eliminate competition on the national level and reduce the amount of international trade.
Many businesses compete in local and niche markets. Only one company, Oldcastle, has gained a significant market share while other notable companies have cornered less than 1.0% of the total market.
The industry adheres to strict environmental regulations regarding emissions and dangerous materials. Precast concrete must also pass OSHA standards for load-bearing and safety.
The industry has a strong support network. The National Precast Association can offer manufacturers benefits, education and consultations to succeed.
The industry has high purchasing costs. Significant cement price changes, like in 2022, can chip away at profitability.
Profit has declined, especially as interest rates rise. Downstream markets have borrowed at higher rates, limiting new projects and demand for precast concrete.
Transportation costs are high. Manufacturers will locate near suppliers and key markets to limit costs.
Manufacturers move to high-population states. These areas have greater housing, utilities and infrastructure needs, which can be filled by the industry.
The utilities construction market is the industry's largest buyer. These facilities are constantly updated, leading to steady demand for precast concrete.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Utilities construction generates the majority of demand for precast and prestressed concrete. This market includes construction contractors that build sanitary and stormwater products. It also consists of companies that demand both water-related utilities and those that build electric power facilities. Buyers purchase precast manholes, stormwater retention structures, curb inlets and catch basins. This market also includes construction companies involved in water and on-site wastewater management and electric power facilities, which need precast septic tanks, grease interceptors and precast poles and beams.

This market includes buyers of precast and prestressed concrete for building roads, bridges, tunnels and highways. Buyers use concrete products to erect bridges, highway off-ramps and overpasses and provide sound insulation for highways and tunnel construction. This market's principal inputs include precast culverts, sound walls and prestressed bridge elements; this market also purchases precast concrete pavement and other similar products. The passage of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Plan (IIJA) in late 2021 appropriated billions of dollars for improvements to transportation infrastructure.

This market includes buyers of precast and prestressed concrete involved in residential and nonresidential building construction. The residential building market is a key consumer of precast concrete floors, wall and roof tiles and concrete building boards. Commercial and institutional building markets use concrete products, including precast slabs and panels, prestressed beams and concrete tiles. This segment also includes markets that build industrial facilities with high concrete content and with walls increasingly being constructed from prestressed concrete panels, beams and trusses. Rising interest rates have made it difficult for potential buyers to finance new projects.

products_and_services.product_description: Manufacturers make casting concrete from concrete placed in a reusable mold. This cast is cured in a controlled environment, transported to the construction site and lifted into place. Precast concrete products are the majority of the industry's sales.
Between precast concrete products and precast building systems, this segment makes up more than 80.0% of the market.

Manufacturers make prestressed concrete by stretching high-strength steel cables or strands between two fixed abutments, then casting concrete on a form placed between the abutments. The concrete then cures, which creates a bond between the cables and the concrete. After the curing process, the cables are cut free of the abutments, causing the cables to relax and compressing the concrete. Prestressed concrete can carry greater loads and span greater distances while maintaining a minimum level of flexibility and strength. Since it is flexible and stress-resistant, contractors use prestressed concrete to build bridges and other large infrastructure products where strength is critical.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Cement is the key ingredient in manufacturing concrete. The price of cement is expected to decline in 2024.
An increase in large residential buildings has brought revenue, but housing starts will slump in 2024, posing a threat.
Utilities construction projects like water systems and power generators are a major demand source. The value will increase in 2024.
Companies use precast concrete for buildings. A higher construction value reflects more durable materials like precast concrete being used.
Investment in precast concrete often requires credit. While access has expanded, interest rate hikes will limit it, though it will surge in 2024.
Precast concrete is used in office buildings. Office rental vacancy will decline in 2024, boosting demand.
Precast manufacturers are labor-intensive. The labor market will expand marginally in 2024.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Tariffs have slowed the import of precast concrete. Foreign manufacturers often leverage inexpensive production and labor to offset high transportation costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A strong US dollar makes foreign goods less expensive
international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic purchasing power increased significantly following the pandemic, enabling inexpensive purchases of foreign precast concrete.
Historically, the sale of excess products to Canada and Mexico comprises a significant share of exports as these two countries are the most prominent international purchasers of precast concrete.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Infrastructure growth in developing economies restricts further export declines
international_trade_points.trade_description: US-made prestressed concrete is especially popular in economies undertaking infrastructure expansion, with the Bahamas emerging as an important export destination.

business_locations.location_description: Florida has the third-highest number of manufacturers in the United States. The high concentration in the Southeast corresponds with the increased consumption of concrete products in transportation infrastructure and the region's extensive residential and commercial building activity.

The Great Lakes region is a hub of industrial activity. It also offers ready access to many cement manufacturers, which provide essential inputs to precast concrete production. The region also facilitates exports to Canada, which accounts for more than 65.0% of industry exports. Industrial markets also make up more than 24.0% of revenue.

Texas accounts for the most industry establishments of any state. Population shifts to Texas have propelled high construction growth rates, attracting a rising number of precast concrete manufacturers. The high cost of transporting precast concrete materials over a long distance encourages production facilities to operate near demand centers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Manufacturers must adhere to a health and safety standard in the workplace in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations. Recently, OSHA has made safety regulations stricter, forcing many companies to update their ladder systems, provide proper safety equipment and employ a fall protection system, including a guardrail or safety net, to meet the new rules.

Environmental regulations determine how wastewater and other potentially hazardous materials are disposed of at precast plants. Process water, which is generated during core operations, can contain potentially toxic metals and elements, including sulfates, hydroxides, grease, oil and chemical derivatives. Precast concrete manufacturers can comply with regulations by pretreating the water, lowering its pH level before discharging it or recycling it into the process again, as long as the water meets quality levels established by the American Society for Testing and Materials.

basis_points.basis_description: Successful precast concrete manufacturers leverage established networks to source less expensive materials than competitors.

basis_points.basis_title: Buyers choose manufacturers based on price and quality
Emphasis on diverse product range exceeding requirements
basis_points.basis_description: The most successful manufacturers place an emphasis on producing a diverse range of products that exceed minimum load-bearing requirements.

basis_points.basis_title: Delivery time is key to success

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is dominated by small-scale manufacturers servicing narrow regional or niche product markets, though, leading companies can scale.
The heavy weight of the raw material inputs and the finished product tends to restrict operations to narrow geographic markets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 3 companies have less than 10% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: The top three companies make up less than 10.0% of industry revenue in 2024.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Only Oldcastle has over 1% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Only Oldcastle has cornered more than 1.0% of the total market.

top_companies.company_name: Grupo Rotoplas S A B De C V

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the Industry's Largest Cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs have remained relatively steady over the past five years. The price of cement has climbed over the past five years which has contributed to keeping purchase costs significant.
The principal material inputs for production include cement, sand and gravel, crushed and broken stone, steel wire, reinforcing mesh and containers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Falters as Construction Sector Scuffles
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has declined over the past five years. The industry is reliant on downstream construction industries for growth. Profit fell alongside the poor nonresidential construction market, specifically in 2020. Profit also sank as rising interest rates forced businesses and individuals to borrow for projects at higher rates. Housing starts, particularly, declined in the latter part of the current period, closing off a large source of growth from the building and landscaping market.

Wage expenses are high and have climbed over the past five years. Wage expenses are nearly double the manufacturing sector average, reflecting the industry's reliance on manual design and molding of precast concrete. Skilled employees are also important for understanding and meeting buyers' individualized needs and forming relationships with downstream markets through timely delivery and customer satisfaction.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital expenditure is significantly higher for large manufacturers. Small and mid-size companies rely on labor to create and pour concrete molds.
Capital expenditure is significantly higher for large manufacturers. Small and mid-size companies rely on labor to create and pour concrete molds.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is vulnerable to shifts in residential and commercial construction markets, as demonstrated during the pandemic. While housing starts blossomed, the nonresidential market collapsed in 2020. Volatility is tempered by more stable demand from publicly funded infrastructure projects like bridges and highways.

As interest rates rise, it becomes more difficult for individuals and businesses to finance new projects, limiting purchases of precast concrete. The housing market has especially suffered, falling dramatically in the latter part of the current period. Similarly, the nonresidential construction market has been unable to make up for declines during the pandemic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Precast concrete manufacturers are exploring the idea of using 3D printing to construct a product without using a form. Even so, this technology shows much more promise for in-place concrete contractors than for prefabricated product manufacturing.

Fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) rebar is a lightweight material manufactured from composite materials. FBR is corrosion-resistant, exhibits higher tensile strength than traditional steel and has been increasingly used for bridge decks and seawalls.

FAQs.question: Have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Precast concretes are heavy and difficult to move inexpensively. Most companies manufacture and distribute goods on a regional basis, insulating somewhat from the heavier trade disruptions experienced by other manufacturing industries.

FAQs.question: Does your produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Operators manufacture prestressed and precast concrete products, which range from slabs and roof tiles for houses, beams and trusses for bridges and highways, water infrastructure products and concrete panels, posts and poles used for electrical distribution facilities.

FAQs.question: Where is your company located in relation to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Companies typically locate themselves near suppliers to cut down on transportation costs and establish a network in a specific region.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored opportunities in new areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Merger and acquisition activity has increased as larger companies acquire smaller companies to expand their product offerings and geographic presence.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Some companies are currently in the early stages of investing in 3D printing to create necessary structures without using a form or mold. This technology will affect smaller projects, like residential construction, than infrastructure and commercial scale operations.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: While some automation occurs, companies require high-skilled labor to meet the customer's specific needs, creating relationships with different downstream markets and ensuring timely delivery.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with multiple trade associations, including the National Precast Association, to stay current on new legislation and trends. Members also receive specific benefits, including performance reports, online courses, certifications and consultation services.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Recently, many companies have started to adopt sustainable practices, including reusing water, recycling packaging and using local materials, to stay ahead of the changing environmental standards. Environmentally friendly building design, which often involves the selection of concrete providers with strong environmental positions, is becoming significantly more common.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margin compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average profit is relatively steady because of high and consistent wage costs.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: It's imperative that companies ensure their equipment is up-to-date. The frequency a company purchases new equipment is directly related to its size and how much capital they use.

FAQs.question: Are you located close to your target markets and suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Having contacts within key markets. Having solid relationships with key construction companies and public sector agencies is essential for securing contracts.

FAQs.question: What downstream ownership links does your company currently have?
FAQs.answer: Owning raw material suppliers secures contracts and lowers purchase costs in the industry. This gives the manufacturer a competitive advantage, helps them plan production and inventory better and bolsters their profit margin.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Locating facilities close to growing end markets helps companies save on transportation costs and enables manufacturers to understand and cater to the needs of different localized markets. Serving as a subcontractor on a large project in your region may help your company gain brand recognition and bidding power for the largest value, highest margin projects.

FAQs.question: How much of your demand for concrete comes from utilities and infrastructure projects? How will your company be affected by the market prevalence of green energy?
FAQs.answer: A large percentage of demand comes from electric, water and gas line project construction. Although industry revenue is insensitive to year-to-year shifts in utility demand, long-term changes to utilities' demands could have dramatic impacts on manufacturers, with large companies being particularly attached to utilities. While some green energy projects, especially hydroelectric and nuclear generation, use large amounts of concrete, environmental sentiment is expected to reduce demand for concrete overall.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly monitor changes in the interest rate?
FAQs.answer: Changes in the interest rate impact precast concrete manufacturers by reducing demand for massive projects where borrowing is necessary, especially buildings.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by slowdowns in the nonresidential office construction market?
FAQs.answer: Precast concrete manufacturers build precast concrete walls, window lintels and other construction components for office buildings. Companies that diversified their clients were better able to weather lows.
